ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really learned to think about my consumption of Popular Culture in a critical way. My entire perspective on consumption of TV, entertainment, movies, has changed.
I learned a ton about how to think through popular culture in an academic context!

I learned how to write cultural criticism and to think critically about why we consume pop culture. This course felt more like training in a new way of thinking about the world than it did an education on any particular topic.

I learned more about religious theory and in our discussions of pop culture, I learned to think much more deeply. I also improved my writing because the assignments required very different writing from my previous Yale classes.
I learned how to craft a better essay and think about how and why we interact with popular culture.
I spent a lot of time this semester learning how to like things other people like.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was the best class I've ever taken at Yale.
I think this is a super interesting course, but I do think connecting back to religion more obviously could help structure it a bit.

The syllabus for this course was fascinating, as were all of our discussions! I loved the writing assignments too, although I do feel that I sometimes would've appreciated having a clearer idea of what was expected of us on each assignment because they were all so different.

The class was amazing. I really enjoyed the mix of readings and the very contemporary pop culture references. The level of discussion in class was very high, which was my favorite part of the class. I also really liked the writing assignments, which stretched my thought processes and skills.

On huge strength is Professor Lofton, who always makes discussion dynamic and interesting. I really liked the range of topics we covered because we explored areas of popular culture that not many people had experienced.
Eclectic selection of readings and other material made this class stand out for me

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the Professor did an excellent job integrating media into the course -- and discussion was always lively!

I thought the discussions worked well virtually, and I appreciated that the homework included movies and other media as well as readings, which kept me from feeling too burnt out. Also thoroughly appreciated that Professor Lofton gave us one extra day off when she sensed that we were all deeply exhausted!
Professor Lofton's flexibility made zoom class during this difficult semester totally manageable.
Having a lot of breakout discussions helped with engagement and more conversation. A wide range of media was used which made the content more engaging.
I dont have any suggestions for Professor Loftons approach to pandemic teaching. It was wonderful!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was incredible. Professor Lofton is brilliant, and she genuinely cares about students. I could not recommend this class more.
Please, please take this class. Prof Lofton will literally make you smarter.
Yes, though it isn't for everyone.

Yes, for sure. Prof Lofton is an engaging discussion leader and class with her is always thought-provoking. I loved this class because we got to choose our own avenues of pop culture to explore and bring our own knowledge to the table.
Yes! This is a fascinating class where you will think through popular culture in unique ways. If you love (or hate) TikTok, Trisha Paytas, and/or BTS -- this class is for you.

If you are a pop culture fan, or simply want to learn more about a lot of weird pop culture phenomena from an intellectual perspective, then 100% YES! Also, this course will make you a better writer of cultural criticism, which is such a valuableand fun!skill.
Absolutely. Professor Lofton is amazing, and the material is unlike any other class I've taken. You'll look at things in a really different light after taking it.
100% yes! Completely changes the way you think and Professor Lofton is amazing!!
Yes
YES IF YOU LOVE YOURSELF TAKE THIS CLASS PROFESSOR LOFTON IS AMAZING
